1.text: Do not boast about tomorrow, for you do not know what a day may bring.

2.text: Let another praise you, and not your own mouth—a stranger, and not your own lips.

3.text: A stone is heavy and sand is a burden, but aggravation from a fool outweighs them both.

4.text: Wrath is cruel and anger is like a flood, but who can withstand jealousy?

5.text: Better an open rebuke than love that is concealed.

6.text: The wounds of a friend are faithful, but the kisses of an enemy are deceitful.

7.text: The soul that is full loathes honey, but to a hungry soul, any bitter thing is sweet.

8.text: Like a bird that strays from its nest is a man who wanders from his home.

9.text: Oil and incense bring joy to the heart, and the counsel of a friend is sweetness to the soul.

10.text: Do not forsake your friend or your father’s friend, and do not go to your brother’s house in the day of your calamity; better a neighbor nearby than a brother far away.

11.text: Be wise, my son, and bring joy to my heart, so that I can answer him who taunts me.

12.text: The prudent see danger and take cover, but the simple keep going and pay the penalty.

13.text: Take the garment of him who posts security for a stranger; get collateral if it is for a foreigner.

14.text: If one blesses his neighbor with a loud voice early in the morning, it will be counted to him as a curse.

15.text: A constant dripping on a rainy day and a contentious woman are alike—

16.text: restraining her is like holding back the wind or grasping oil with one’s right hand.

17.text: As iron sharpens iron, so one man sharpens another.

18.text: Whoever tends a fig tree will eat its fruit, and he who looks after his master will be honored.

19.text: As water reflects the face, so the heart reflects the true man.

20.text: Sheol and Abaddon are never satisfied; so the eyes of man are never satisfied.

21.text: A crucible for silver and a furnace for gold, but a man is tested by the praise accorded him.

22.text: Though you grind a fool like grain with mortar and a pestle, yet his folly will not depart from him.

23.text: Be sure to know the state of your flocks, and pay close attention to your herds;

24.text: for riches are not forever, nor does a crown endure to every generation.

25.text: When hay is removed and new growth appears and the grass from the hills is gathered,

26.text: the lambs will provide you with clothing, and the goats with the price of a field.

27.text: You will have plenty of goats’ milk to feed you—food for your household and nourishment for your maidservants.
